SEARCH
Package gw.plugin.financials

Interface IAggregateLimitTransactionPlugin

All Superinterfaces:
InternalPlugin, Remote
All Known Implementing Classes:
AggregateLimitTransactionPluginImpl
public interface IAggregateLimitTransactionPlugin extends InternalPlugin
This plugin, together with the aggregate limit's coverage lines, determine whether a particular limit applies to a transaction.

The plugin has two responsibilities

  • Given a transaction and an aggregate limit, determine whether the transaction applies toward the limit.
  • Determine if a change to a transaction (or related entity) may alter the applicability of a transaction to some limit.
The first responsibility is straightforward. The second is a little trickier. When transaction related information changes, ClaimCenter needs to know if any aggregate limits should be recalculated. ClaimCenter has built in checks for known changes that trigger recalculation (such as changing the amount of a transaction, or adding a new coverage line to an aggregate limit). But if a customer has added their own logic to determine applicability then a completely different type of change may need to trigger recalculation.

For example a customer might add a flag to claim that determines whether transactions on the claim are included in aggregate limits. In such a case ClaimCenter would have to know that changes to the claim field could trigger recalculation of the aggregate limit values. So this plugin has to give customers a way to communicate:

  • What type of entities can possibly trigger a change in applicability
  • Whether a particular change to one of those entities does trigger such a change

The out of box implementation of this plugin implements the standard behavior where transaction applicability is decided by the aggregatelimitused-config.xml configuration file. Customers can choose to add to this standard implementation (e.g. by creating their own plugin implementation that delegates to the out of box implementation as needed) or they can entirely replace it, in which case aggregatelimitused-config.xml is ignored when considering transaction applicability.

Deploying a new implementation of this plugin will potentially leave many aggregate limits in an incorrect state (for example the change might mean that many more existing transactions should apply to limits). After such a change it is the customer's responsibility to force a rebuild of all limits, if they want them to be brought up to date. Even such a forced rebuild (done using the "Aggregate Limit Calculations" batch process) cannot correctly calculate limit values for limits that reference archived claims.

  • Method Details

    • aggregateLimitApplies

      boolean aggregateLimitApplies(AggregateLimit limit, Transaction transaction)
      Does the given aggregate limit apply to the given transaction? This check should rely only on values stored in entities. For example it shouldn't return different values depending on the age of the transaction, as ClaimCenter would have no way of detecting when the transaction age should trigger a change.

      If this check depends on entities other than Transaction then the typesWhichAffectApplicability() method should be overridden as well, to return those entity types.

      The out of box implementation of this plugin implements this check by calling the aggregate limit's configurationAppliesTo(transaction) method, which consults the aggregate limit configuration in aggregatelimitused-config.xml to see whether the transaction applies to the limit. Most customer implementations will want to call this method in addition to their own custom logic, but it is not a requirement; a customer could choose to ignore the configuration in some situations.

      Parameters:
      limit - a non null aggregate limit
      transaction - a non null transaction
      Returns:
      true if the limit should apply, false otherwise

    • typesWhichAffectApplicability

      Set<IEntityType> typesWhichAffectApplicability()
      The set of types which can affect whether a limit should apply to a transaction. This set should usually include Transaction unless the system has been configured so that changes to the transaction itself do not affect applicability.

      The out of box implementation of this method returns a set containing just Transaction

      Returns:
      a non null, but possibly empty, set

    • claimWithChangedTransactionApplicability

      Claim claimWithChangedTransactionApplicability(KeyableBean modifiedEntity)
      Examines the given modified entity and determines if it has changed in a way that may change the applicability of a limit to one or more transactions. If so, return the claim to which the transaction(s) belong. ClaimCenter will then recalculate the aggregate limit values associated with this claim.

      This method will only be called for a modified entity whose type is one of the types specified b typesWhichAffectApplicability(). The implementation of the method will have to check the type of the entity and cast it to do any type specific checks.

      The modified entity may be inserted (New/isNew()), updated (Changed/isChanged()) or removed (Retired, for retireable entities).

      This method should not return a claim if the only thing that has changed is an out of box transaction or aggregate limit field that always causes aggregate limit recalculation (such as a transaction's amount, or a coverage line's coverage type); ClaimCenter already checks these fields. The intent is to let ClaimCenter know about changes that the out of box logic would not normally consider relevant, such as changes to extension fields or custom entities.

      The out of box implementation of this method checks if any transaction fields relevant to the aggregate limit configuration file (aggregatelimitused-config.xml) have changed.

      Parameters:
      modifiedEntity - a non null modified entity, guaranteed to be an entity whose type is in the set returned by typesWhichAffectApplicability().
      Returns:
      if the change to this entity could change the applicability of one or more transactions to some limit, then return the claim that owns the affected transaction(s). Otherwise return null.
